title: Japanese destroyer Ōshio
text:
was the second of ten s built for the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> in the mid-1930s under the <a href="2nd%20Naval%20Armaments%20Supplement%20Programme%20%28Japan%2C%201934%29">Circle Two Supplementary Naval Expansion Program</a> ("Maru Ni Keikaku").
History.
The "Asashio"-class destroyers were larger and more capable that the preceding , as Japanese naval architects were no longer constrained by the provisions of the <a href="London%20Naval%20Treaty">London Naval Treaty</a>. These <a href="light%20cruiser">light cruiser</a>-sized vessels were designed to take advantage of Japan’s lead in <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> technology, and to accompany the Japanese main striking force and in both day and night attacks against the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> as it advanced across the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>, according to Japanese naval strategic projections. Despite being one of the most powerful classes of destroyers in the world at the time of their completion, none survived the <a href="Pacific%20War">Pacific War</a>.
"Ōshio", built at the <a href="Maizuru%20Naval%20Arsenal">Maizuru Naval Arsenal</a> was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 5 August 1936, <a href="Ship%20launching">launched</a> on 19 April 1937 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 31 October 1937.
Operational history.
At the time of the <a href="attack%20on%20Pearl%20Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a>, "Ōshio" was assigned to Destroyer Division 8 (Desdiv 8), and a member of Destroyer Squadron 2 (Desron 2) of the <a href="IJN%202nd%20Fleet">IJN 2nd Fleet</a>, escorting Admiral <a href="Nobutake%20Kond%C5%8D">Nobutake Kondō</a>'s Southern Force Main Body out of <a href="Mako%20Guard%20District">Mako Guard District</a> as distant cover to the <a href="Battle%20of%20Malaya">Malaya</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Philippines%20%281941-42%29">Philippines</a> invasion forces in December 1941.
"Ōshio" escorted a Malaya troop convoy from Mako towards <a href="Singora">Singora</a>, then put into <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> on 5 January 1942. She escorted another troop convoy to <a href="Davao%20City">Davao</a>, and then accompanied the <a href="Battle%20of%20Ambon">Ambon invasion</a> force (31 January), the <a href="Makassar">Makassar</a> invasion force (8 February) and the <a href="Bali">Bali</a>/<a href="Lombok">Lombok</a> invasion force (18 February).
On the night of 19 February 1942, "Ōshio" participated in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Badoeng%20Strait">Battle of Badoeng Strait</a>. "Ōshio" was guarding the transport "Sasago Maru" off <a href="Bali">Bali</a> when an <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied</a> fleet attacked. During the battle, "Ōshio" has been credited with assisting in sinking the <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20Navy">Dutch</a> destroyer with a <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>, plus gunnery hits on the Dutch light cruiser and the American destroyer . "Ōshio" suffered medium damage, with seven crewmen killed.
In March, after emergency repairs at Makassar, "Ōshio" returned to <a href="Yokosuka%20Naval%20Arsenal">Yokosuka Naval Arsenal</a> for repairs, which lasted to the end of the year.
In early January 1943, "Ōshio" was sent from <a href="Maizuru%20Naval%20District">Maizuru</a> to <a href="Shortland%20Island">Shortland Island</a>, and participated in three missions to evacuate surviving Japanese troops from <a href="Guadalcanal">Guadalcanal</a> in early February. On 20 February, together with her <a href="sister%20ship">sister ship</a> , she was attacked by the <a href="submarine">submarine</a> off <a href="Wewak">Wewak</a>, <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>. "Ōshio" was hit by a torpedo, which flooded her engine room and killed eight crewmen. "Arashio" attempted to tow her, but her <a href="keel">keel</a> was fatally damaged, and she sank approximately northeast of <a href="Manus%20Island">Manus Island</a> at position . She was removed from the <a href="navy%20list">navy list</a> on 1 April 1943.
